meta.description: Scientific evidence base for BSI (Behavioral Sandbox Incubator) - Startup validation through behavioral economics simulation

behavioral_theories.name: Prospect Theory
behavioral_theories.citation: Kahneman, D., & Tversky, A. (1979). Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision under Risk. Econometrica, 47(2), 263-291.
behavioral_theories.finding: People make decisions based on potential gains and losses relative to a reference point, not absolute outcomes. Loss aversion: losses loom larger than equivalent gains (λ ≈ 2.25).
key_insights: Losses are psychologically 2.25x more impactful than equivalent gains
People are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking to avoid losses
Reference point (status quo) heavily influences decision-making
behavioral_theories.application_context: Freemium models trigger endowment effect. Users perceive switching to paid tier as 'loss' of free features rather than 'gain' of premium features.

behavioral_theories.name: Endowment Effect
behavioral_theories.citation: Thaler, R. H. (1980). Toward a positive theory of consumer choice. Journal of Economic Behavior & Organization, 1(1), 39-60.
behavioral_theories.finding: People ascribe more value to things merely because they own them. Ownership creates psychological attachment that inflates perceived value by 80-100%.
key_insights: Willingness to Accept (WTA) > Willingness to Pay (WTP) by factor of ~2
Immediate ownership creates instant valuation bias
Free trials convert poorly if users don't perceive ownership
behavioral_theories.application_context: Freemium users overvalue free tier features, resist upgrading. 'Loss' framing (You'll lose access to X) outperforms 'gain' framing (You'll get access to Y) by 47%.

behavioral_theories.name: Social Proof Principle
behavioral_theories.citation: Cialdini, R. B. (2006). Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion (Revised Edition). Harper Business.
behavioral_theories.finding: People look to others' behavior to determine their own, especially under uncertainty. Social proof effect amplifies when: (1) Similarity high, (2) Uncertainty high, (3) Number of people large.
key_insights: 15-20% adoption rate triggers 'bandwagon effect' in tech products
Visible user count increases conversion by 34%
Peer recommendations 5x more influential than advertising
behavioral_theories.application_context: Network effects in consumer apps. Once 15% of target market adopts, viral growth accelerates exponentially. Critical for marketplace/social platforms.

behavioral_theories.name: Anchoring and Adjustment Heuristic
behavioral_theories.authors: Ariely, D., Loewenstein, G., & Prelec, D.
behavioral_theories.citation: Ariely, D., Loewenstein, G., & Prelec, D. (2003). Coherent Arbitrariness: Stable Demand Curves Without Stable Preferences. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 118(1), 73-106.
behavioral_theories.finding: Initial price exposure creates lasting anchor point. Subsequent price judgments influenced by first price seen, even if arbitrary. Effect persists across multiple decisions.
key_insights: First price seen influences willingness to pay by 40-60%
Decoy pricing: Middle tier becomes anchor for premium tier
Three-tier pricing optimizes for middle tier (60-70% choose it)
behavioral_theories.application_context: SaaS pricing strategy. Three-tier pricing with decoy (high-priced tier) makes middle tier appear valuable. Middle tier selection increases from 35% (two-tier) to 65% (three-tier).

behavioral_theories.name: Choice Overload Effect
behavioral_theories.authors: Iyengar, S. S., & Lepper, M. R.
behavioral_theories.publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
behavioral_theories.citation: Iyengar, S. S., & Lepper, M. R. (2000). When choice is demotivating: Can one desire too much of a good thing? Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 79(6), 995-1006.
behavioral_theories.finding: Too many options reduce decision quality and satisfaction. Optimal choice set: 3-5 options. Beyond 7 options, decision paralysis increases exponentially.
key_insights: 6 jam varieties → 30% purchase rate. 24 varieties → 3% purchase rate
Three pricing tiers optimal for conversion
Each additional option reduces conversion by 8-10%
behavioral_theories.application_context: Product feature selection and pricing tiers. Startups offering too many SKUs/plans see lower conversion. Simplification increases purchase probability 22%.

behavioral_theories.name: Scarcity and Urgency Effects
behavioral_theories.citation: Cialdini, R. B. (2006). Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion (Revised Edition). Harper Business.
behavioral_theories.finding: Perceived scarcity increases desire and valuation. Time-limited offers and limited quantity both trigger urgency, but for different psychological reasons.
key_insights: Countdown timers increase urgency perception by 42%
'Only X left' messaging increases purchase intent by 31%
behavioral_theories.application_context: Flash sales, limited beta access, early-bird pricing. FOMO (Fear of Missing Out) particularly effective for millennial/Gen-Z segments (effect 1.8x stronger).

real_world_benchmarks.citation: Eisenmann, T., Barley, L., & Kind, L. (2011). Dropbox: 'It Just Works'. Harvard Business School Case 811-065.
real_world_benchmarks.insights: Referral program (both parties get free storage) reduced CAC by 60%. Endowment effect: Users who filled 75% of free storage converted at 18% (4.5x baseline).
real_world_benchmarks.relevance_to_simulation: Benchmark for freemium conversion rates. Loss aversion manifests when free storage nearly full.

real_world_benchmarks.citation: Spotify Technology S.A. (2019). Q4 2018 Earnings Report.
real_world_benchmarks.insights: Premium retention 2x higher than free. Conversion peaks at 6 weeks (habitual use formed). Ad interruptions create pain point that drives upgrade (loss aversion + endowment).
real_world_benchmarks.relevance_to_simulation: Demonstrates endowment effect over time. Users who form 6-week habit perceive free tier as 'owned', making premium upgrade feel like loss avoidance.

real_world_benchmarks.source: Duolingo Research Paper - A/B Testing Results
real_world_benchmarks.citation: Settles, B., & Meeder, B. (2016). A Trainable Spaced Repetition Model for Language Learning. ACL.
real_world_benchmarks.insights: Streak mechanic leverages loss aversion (don't break the streak). Social leaderboards trigger social proof. Combined effects multiplicative, not additive.
real_world_benchmarks.relevance_to_simulation: Quantifies behavioral mechanism strength. Loss aversion (streak) + social proof (leaderboard) = 51% + 34% = 85% total effect (compounding).

real_world_benchmarks.citation: Price Intelligently. (2019). SaaS Pricing Strategy Report.
real_world_benchmarks.insights: Decoy effect: Expensive top tier rarely chosen (8%), but existence makes middle tier appear reasonable. Revenue per customer increases 31% with three-tier vs two-tier.
real_world_benchmarks.relevance_to_simulation: Anchoring + decoy pricing parameters. High anchor shifts perceived value upward for all tiers.

simulation_scenarios.description: Student startup building campus food delivery app. Testing optimal revenue model.
EdTech startup testing pricing model for university students. Course catalog: 50+ courses.
Productivity SaaS for freelancers/SMBs. Testing tiered pricing strategy.

validation_methodology.external_validation: Compare simulation results against real-world benchmarks (Dropbox, Spotify, Duolingo). Acceptable error margin: ±5%.
